statement.p:
Solve the system by substitution: 2x \amp = y+7 2y \amp = 14-3x
Step 1
Choose one of the equations, and solve for one of the variables.
Step 2
Substitute this new expression for x or y into the other equation.
Step 3
Notice that the new equation has only one variable. Solve the equation.
Step 4
Substitute the answer to Step 3 into the result of Step 1 to find the other variable. Write your solution as an ordered pair.

Solve the system by elimination: 3x+5y \amp = 1 2x-3y \amp = 7
Step 1
We choose to eliminate x. Multiply the first equation by 2 and the second equation by -3. (Why?) \alert{2}[3x+5y=1] \amp\rightarrow \hphantom{other side of equation} \alert{-3}[2x-3y=7] \amp\rightarrow \hphantom{other side of equation}
Step 2
The coefficients of x are now opposites. Add the two equations together.
Step 3
Solve the new equation for the remaining variable.
Step 4
Use substitution to find the other variable. Write your solution as an ordered pair.

statement.p: Geologists can calculate the distance from their seismograph to the epicenter of an earthquake by timing the arrival of the P and S waves. They know that, for this earthquake, P waves travel at about 5.4 miles per second and S waves travel at 3.0 miles per second. If the P waves arrived 3 minutes before the S waves, how far away is the epicenter of the quake?
